raw_text:
Bortolami predicts dour contest
 
 Italy skipper Marco Bortolami believes Saturday's Six Nations contest against Scotland will be a scrappy encounter.
 
 With both sides looking for their first win of the championship, the third-round game at Murrayfield has been billed as a wooden-spoon decider. And Bortolami feels the Edinburgh contest could end up being a bruising battle of the packs. "It will not be a pretty game because both teams are desperate to gain their first win," said the lock forward. Italy have only recorded three wins since they joined the Six Nations in 2000, but two of those have come against Scotland. This year, Italy opened up with a stubborn display against Ireland but ended up losing 28-17.
 
 However, they were thoroughly outplayed by an impressive Welsh side in Rome last time out. Now the Italians travel to Edinburgh hoping to claim their first away win in the Six Nations. "Scotland played extremely well against France in Paris but not so well when Ireland came to Edinburgh," said Bortolami. "We are still very disappointed with our last game against Wales in Rome and we are thoroughly determined to right the wrongs. "As a nation, our quest is to be respected as a team worthy of a place in this tournament and we can only do this by winning games."
llama3.2:1b: Marco Bortolami predicts Italy will lose to Scotland on Saturday's Six Nations contest due to both teams' desperation for their first win of the championship.

Despite being underdogs, Bortolami believes Italy have a strong chance of winning against Scotland despite having only recorded three wins since joining the competition in 2000, and losing 28-17 to Ireland earlier this year.

The Italian lock forward believes the third-round match at Murrayfield could end up being a bruising battle of the packs, with Italy hoping to claim their first away win in the tournament.

Both teams are desperate for their first win, making it a likely "bruising" battle.
Italy's previous match was an improvement after a loss against Ireland, but they were defeated by Wales, leaving them seeking a first away victory in the tournament.
They hope to right their wrongs and earn respect as worthy contenders.

The Scots opened up with a good start in Rome but were defeated 28-17 by Wales.
Bortolami is optimistic about his team's performance and states that they are "still very disappointed with their last game against Wales."

Despite Italy's poor record since joining the league in 2000 (3 wins out of 4), they aim to make amends by claiming their first away win in the tournament, hoping to earn respect as a formidable team worthy of participation in the Six Nations.

Believing it will be a physical contest, particularly focusing on the scrums, Bortolami notes Italy's struggles since joining the tournament but acknowledges one victory over Scotland.
The team aims to improve after losing 28-17 to Ireland and being outplayed by Wales in Rome, hoping for their first away win in this competition.
